oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Subcellular Mechanisms of Intropic Agents
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gwathmey, Judith K.
Morgan, James P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: intracellular calcium concentration
intropic agent
action mechanism
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: It is well known that the calcium ion (Ca⁺⁺) plays a central role in excitation-contraction coupling of the mammalian heart. Most interventions with positive or negative intropic effects on the heart either alter the intracellular calcium concentration, change the responsiveness of the myofilaments to calcium, or both. The most direct way to monitor an intropic agent's effect and determine its mechanism of action is to monitor intracellular Ca⁺⁺ transients and correlate them with mechanical events. Aequorin, a bioluminescent indicator that emits light when it binds to free ionized calcium was used to monitor intracellular Ca⁺⁺ levels. Changes in the amplitude and time course of the calcium transient correlate with known subcellular actions of the agents investigated. This correlation has provided the basis for a functional classification scheme· that can be used to investigate drugs with unknown mechanisms of action.
